6.92.text:
I would like to tell you a bit about the work,
some of the work,

9.98.text:
we are trying to do, which is trying to improve
imaging of prostate cancer,

15.43.text: and I’ll try to explain why.

17.02.text:
So, I just need to tell you I have some shares
in a company

22.60.text:
that is working out through one of the patents
that I did,

26.32.text:
but it is not relevant to this, but I am obliged
to tell people, by law.

32.74.text:
So this is the man’s journey through prostate
cancer.

36.87.text:
I don’t know if there is a mouse I could
use.

42.62.text: No, never mind. I’ll just explain.

46.20.text:
On the left hand side you can see that diagnosis
occurs,

49.28.text: but probably by the stage that diagnosis occurs

53.18.text:
men have maybe had the disease for five to
ten years already.

58.50.text:
And then the choices seem to be either watchful
waiting these days,

64.52.text:
it used to be surgery or radiation, but if
you have a low Gleason score,

70.25.text:
and probably all of you know what a Gleason
score is.

73.32.text:
It’s a grading of the cancer and there are
two bits that they look at,

78.53.text:
they just say the bit that’s the worst and
the bit that’s, I mean sorry,

82.48.text:
the bit that’s the most common has a grade
from one to five

86.54.text:
and the next bit that’s the next most common
has a grade from one to five,

90.93.text:
and they add those two numbers together to
make a Gleason score.

94.05.text:
So, if your Gleason score is six, it’s now
considered to be pretty mild,

100.55.text:
and you might be advised to go on watchful
waiting

105.32.text:
But, if it’s seven or above, then usually
the choices are

110.17.text:
that you should do something actively about
it,

112.52.text: like and operation or having radiation.

115.36.text: So, most men, after that, get better.

120.21.text:
But some men then, after a few years, find
that they have a rising PSA.

125.53.text:
That’s the blood test for prostate specific
antigen.

129.55.text: And the reason that it’s so useful

132.28.text: it’s now not being used so much for diagnosis,

135.21.text:
but it’s incredibly useful once you know
a man has prostate cancer,

139.78.text:
because it goes up and down with the volume
of the cancer, usually.

143.99.text: There are some cases where that does not happen,

147.24.text: but as a general generalisation it does.

150.36.text:
And so the treatment for that is some kind
of androgen ablation,

156.38.text:
or androgen therapy, which blocks the production
of testosterone.

165.14.text: In the olden days they used to castrate men.

167.42.text: That’s not done so much now.

169.52.text: They use drugs instead to achieve that result.

173.40.text:
But the reason that the PSA goes down is that
it’s actually driven by androgen,

181.03.text:
so the male hormone drives the production
of PSA.

185.61.text: PSA is an enzyme, which is found in the ejaculate,

189.82.text:
and its role is to break down the little clot
that forms in the ejaculate,

196.78.text:
so that the sperm can swim out and do what
they need to do.

201.35.text: So it also makes fluids in the prostate.

204.86.text: So PSA is controlled by androgen.

207.33.text: So, if you monitor the PSA levels,

210.15.text:
its giving you an idea of what’s happening
with the androgen.

213.35.text:
And it turns out that prostate cancer is very
much androgen dependent

219.45.text:
So, initially, the Chinese eunuchs who used
to look after the harems were all castrated,

226.54.text:
and they, none of them, ever developed prostate
cancer.

230.70.text:
So, if you didn’t want to develop prostate
cancer,

233.17.text:
you could become a nice boy soprano and sing
up high for the rest of your life.

237.43.text: But that isn’t of course what happens.

239.26.text:
But it was one of the ways in which it was
found that the androgen was so important.

243.83.text: So, when that goes back up

246.13.text:
the androgen ablation usually brings the PSA
down again in many patients,

251.81.text:
but there are some who then go on to have
another rise in prostate cancer.

258.15.text: So by this stage, on this end of the graph,

260.63.text: we’re now talking about more advanced disease.

263.34.text:
The beginning one was sort of early disease,
but a proportion of men get advanced disease.

270.49.text:
And when we are working in research, as I
am, you tend to concentrate on this end

276.91.text:
because the surgery and the radiation can
work very well for many men at the early stage.

281.90.text:
So, we are trying to work out how we can save
men who have developed advanced stage

288.14.text:
So that’s why I’m talking about that end
of the spectrum.

292.00.text:
So, if you’re newly diagnosed I don’t
want you to think that, you know,

297.43.text:
I’m telling you, a song of doom about your
life expectancy, because I’m not.

303.75.text:
I’m trying to tell you about how we might
treat and do things for men with late stage

312.31.text:
So when that goes up, as you can see by that
brown line,

316.56.text:
initially the cancer is called androgen dependent
or androgen sensitive.

325.32.text:
it now does not seem to need the hormone any
more, or castrate resistant.

330.78.text:
And at that time, or even a bit before it,
it starts to spread

335.06.text:
and it spreads to other organs and in particular
it goes to the bones.

342.79.text:
So bony metastases, they’re secondary deposits
of cancer in the bone,

346.08.text: are very common in late stage prostate cancer.

357.57.text:
So this is just to explain what goes on in
the late stage cancer.

363.50.text:
You can still treat late stage cancer, which
now don’t seem to be hormone dependent,

369.51.text: with some new drugs that have been discovered.

372.99.text:
And what’s happening is the prostate cancer
actually makes its own androgen.

377.93.text:
So after you’ve taken away the androgen,
by using androgen ablative therapies,

384.39.text: it actually starts to make its own.

386.85.text:
I’ve always said the prostate’s the second
brain, but people don’t like that answer.

392.32.text:
But they do, and, there are several mechanisms
by which this can happen.

399.91.text: First of all, it uses a back door pathway,

403.49.text:
which is not the normal pathway of metabolism
for making the androgen,

407.85.text: in order to make androgen in the prostate.

411.01.text:
And the androgen binds to a receptor on the
cell, which is on the surface of the cell.

415.39.text:
I mean, it binds, it carries it inside of
the cell to the nucleus of the cell

420.21.text: where it turns on a whole lot of genes.

422.69.text:
And another mechanism of getting over the
need for androgen

428.17.text:
is that you get hypersensitivity of the androgen
receptor itself,

432.91.text:
so that it can bind other hormones as well
as testosterone.

436.47.text:
It can bind progesterone and oestrogen and
other kinds of corticosteroids,

443.36.text:
so it does not need the androgen in order
to perform its work.

447.82.text:
Or you can get mutations in that androgen
receptor,

453.04.text:
or you can have multiple copies of the androgen
receptor.

455.86.text:
So that if the level of testosterone is extremely
low it can still be reactive.

461.93.text:
So the drugs have to be designed to work to
overcome these kinds of mechanisms

475.89.text:
This shows that backdoor pathway, so don’t
worry about that.

478.90.text:
But if you can understand those mechanisms,
then you can actually design new therapies.

484.15.text:
So that’s what this slide is really telling
you.

489.86.text: Now I’m coming back to this one again,

491.98.text:
because what happens is that we really desperately
need imaging to tell us

499.80.text: “Do you really have a bad prostate cancer?”

503.02.text:
“Do you have a cancer that isn’t too bad,
even though the Gleason score mightn’t say

507.94.text: But should we be using surveillance?

512.01.text:
That means that you monitor the PSA every
six months

514.95.text:
and maybe do some more imaging in a year’s
time.

517.92.text:
Should you be doing that, or should you be
going on to surgery or radiation?

522.38.text:
We need to be able to make those decisions
better,

525.06.text:
and if we could image the cancer and clearly
see the cancer there,

529.49.text:
we could do that with much more precision
and give better advice to men

533.19.text:
as to what sort of treatment might be good
for them.

537.35.text: And similarly, if we’re using treatments,

539.65.text:
these are just new treatments that have come
up in the last five years.

543.23.text:
I mean a few years ago we did not have any
treatments for late stage cancer.

547.74.text: Now there’s a whole series of drugs.

550.12.text:
Some of them are chemotherapy, so Docetaxel
and Cabazitaxel.

555.52.text:
It is an immune type of therapy that inhibits
the prostate cancer from growing.

561.09.text:
And the Abiraterone and Enzalutamide are aimed
at attacking the androgen receptor

568.33.text: And the 223 Radium is a radioactive substance,

575.03.text:
which also delivers a sort of high level of
radiotherapy locally.

579.06.text:
So, we need it to know, not only for diagnosing,
but for treating.

584.15.text:
A lot of these treatments work in some men
and not other men.

588.37.text:
And they have quite nasty side effects in
some men and not other men.

594.26.text:
So if you’re unfortunate and have a bad
response and get very sick with having, say,

600.71.text:
Docetaxel, we need to know is it working so
that we can stop it a bit sooner,

605.90.text:
or should we keep going and putting people
through these nasty side effects

612.76.text:
But if we could image the cancer well we could
tell a bit earlier whether that’s working,

618.02.text:
and that would help with the management of
the disease.

622.61.text:
So, I’ve just put up here - and I don’t
expect you to read it –

627.70.text:
it’s a great pile of clinical trials that
are going with all these new drugs.

632.70.text:
So it’s just to show you that and awful
lot is now happening world-wide with all these

639.17.text: And clinical trials are usually randomised,

641.44.text:
so a patient will be given one treatment or
not a treatment,

646.82.text:
so that you can actually compare what would
happen to them over time.

650.00.text:
And if the clinical trials aren’t done in
that manner,

652.97.text:
then you can’t really draw appropriate conclusions
about how good the treatment is.

657.74.text:
But this is just to show you there’s all
these trials and, in addition,

662.36.text:
whilst I showed you a whole series of drugs
that were there,

666.41.text: we don’t know if we should combine the drugs.

669.54.text:
And if we should combine the drugs, or treat
with one then another,

674.35.text: what order should we give those drugs in.

676.89.text:
Because sometimes if you combine them they’re
better,

679.55.text: sometimes if you combine them it make it worse.

682.33.text:
And sometimes if you give one first you can’t
use another one.

686.02.text:
And those kinds of decisions are quite difficult
to make.

690.70.text:
So that very much is what is going on in that
space at the moment.

695.25.text:
And one of the things that happens when you
use some of the new drugs

699.57.text:
is that the androgen receptor, which is very
complicated molecule,

704.11.text: and up the top is the normal androgen receptor.

708.08.text:
It’s got different domains and the one on
the right, which is sticking out called LBD,

714.00.text: is called the ligand binding domain.

717.21.text:
But what happens when you treat with these
brand new drugs,

720.47.text: which are very powerful inhibitors of androgen,

723.94.text:
is that you select for a variant of the androgen
receptor,

728.70.text:
which maybe present already, and it has no
ligand binding domain.

735.16.text:
So it actually works very strongly whether
the androgen is there or not there.

741.13.text:
So you’re not achieving the result that
you want.

744.57.text:
And some of the new findings are that this
particular variant,

748.58.text:
which is AR-V7 is actually coming up after
these therapies.

757.76.text:
And when you give those treatments, and if
the patient has AR-V7,

763.49.text:
you can see on the slide on the left the response
of the people to drugs.

770.03.text: So, the black line is your sort of zero line

773.65.text:
and the yellow ones have got that variant
and they’re not responding.

777.88.text:
The ones that are blue are responding, so
they’re actually getting better.

781.59.text:
So, this is a new problem which has just recently
come to people’s notice

787.12.text: after these very new drugs have been developed.

790.33.text: So still haven’t really got a cure.

792.71.text:
We can prolong lives and make people sort
of have a chronic disease.

798.31.text: This is for advanced stage cancer.

799.69.text:
So let me stress that, because if it is early
stage cancer,

804.00.text:
some people respond beautifully to prostatectomy
or radiation

808.62.text:
So I’m talking about the advanced disease,
which we are trying to concentrate on.

814.90.text:
So, let’s talk about how we work out what
to do.

821.98.text:
Most patients I stratified into risk strategies,
risk categories using clinical staging,

829.56.text: which is based on how bad your cancer is.

833.98.text: How sick you are: things like that;

836.61.text:
the level of prostate cancer antigen in the
blood and the biopsy grading.

842.50.text:
If they’re under-staged, and the treatment
is given,

847.42.text: then that can lead to an earlier recurrence.

850.08.text:
We call it a biochemical recurrence because
the PSA comes back up

859.18.text:
they might be treated more aggressively than
they need to be treated.

863.31.text:
So we need something to tell us what’s going
on.

866.98.text:
And we need either diagnostic tests or, perhaps
what I have not mentioned

871.92.text:
is that whilst a lot of men get prostate cancer,
and as you get older,

877.43.text: you are more likely to get it.

879.43.text:
So by the time people are eighty, eighty percent
of men have prostate cancer,

883.69.text: But it might not be a very aggressive disease.

887.26.text:
And we still don’t have a marker which tells
us this disease

891.65.text:
is only going to cause changes that aren’t
really going to affect the man’s life

896.93.text: and this disease is going to be really aggressive.

899.54.text: We don’t have those biomarkers yet.

901.07.text:
We’re searching for them desperately, but
we don’t have those biomarkers.

909.05.text:
Well, when men go to have a biopsy done, it’s
actually changing now but this was the norm.

917.84.text:
They might have a transrectal ultrasound guided
prostate biopsy.

924.33.text: That means a probe is put in through the rectum

927.39.text:
and it goes to specific areas which are predefined
in the prostate

932.00.text:
and takes little pieces so the histology can
be done and something can be done about it.

938.40.text:
But if you then do a radical prostatectomy
on men who have had those

945.23.text: and do what is called a whole mount,

947.55.text:
which means that you cut through the whole
prostate

949.86.text: and you go through every section of the prostate.

951.84.text:
It’s a huge amount of work for the pathologist
to do that.

955.05.text:
They often find that staging that came from
those pre-organised biopsies is incorrect.

961.87.text: It might be under-staged or it might be over-staged.

967.08.text:
And the other problem is that if your biopsy
is taken through the rectum

971.93.text:
and the cancer is on the other side of the
prostate it’s not part of what’s biopsied.

980.17.text: So, you can miss out on it.

983.09.text: So we need some other ways of doing it.

986.88.text:
And also within the prostate, this is true
for most cancers,

991.24.text:
but it’s especially so for the prostate,
you can have multiple foci of cancers.

997.28.text:
So, there might be one at the top and one
next to it and down here.

1004.45.text:
And when they spread from the prostate to
other tissues

1009.21.text:
they can actually spread, say, from the prostate
to a lymph node or to the bone,

1013.96.text: where they form the bone metastases.

1016.46.text: And then they can spread again.

1017.90.text: And instead of spreading from the prostate

1020.18.text:
they can actually spread from the one that’s
in the bone to somewhere else.

1024.00.text:
Or they can spread from one that’s in the
lymph node to somewhere else.

1028.04.text:
So, it’s an incredibly complicated disease
to try and study

1034.02.text: and find new methods to look after.

1039.13.text:
So, for lymph node detection, they’ve been
using MRI, magnetic resonance imaging.

1048.36.text: Has anyone had an MRI here?

1050.19.text: Yes. So you know what it is.

1053.27.text: And they’re now using special types of MRI,

1057.00.text:
where they look at function as well as looking
at the actual tumour.

1062.39.text: And what had been said before was that

1065.36.text:
even when you use some of the functional imaging,
which I’ve mentioned there,

1070.45.text:
you can’t detect a lymph node involvement
unless it is bigger than eight millimetres.

1076.05.text:
Eight millimetres is pretty tiny, but if it
is smaller than that you can’t see it.

1081.30.text:
So you actually need to use nanoparticles
to enhance the MRI

1085.99.text: in order to see that by special techniques.

1089.09.text: So I’ll tell you a bit more about those.

1092.41.text:
So, even with the special MRI, and they’ve
now got a new system for grading the MRI,

1102.06.text:
called PIRAD, which is the I forget what it’s
called, the predictive value.

1109.59.text: You are still missing out on some of the tumours.

1115.03.text:
So in the PA Hospital we’ve now got a new
instrument which is the PET MRI,

1119.93.text:
so we can do positive emissions tomography
at the same time.

1123.54.text: And I’ll tell you a bit about that too.

1126.78.text:
So, just to reiterate, prostate cancer is
currently imaged by transrectal ultrasound,

1135.64.text:
magnetic resonance imaging, computed tomography
which is another form of imaging,

1143.70.text: But we are still not getting our answers.

1146.70.text:
We need better tools, both to diagnose and
assist the response.

1151.58.text: And so we set about to develop new methods

1154.05.text: to improve the imaging in the lab using models.

1159.00.text:
Not men but mouse models or human cancers
growing in mice that are immunodeficient.

1166.42.text:
We can actually take biopsies from men and
put them into mice

1171.96.text:
and if they have not got a proper immune response
they will grow up

1175.04.text: and we can see what is going on.

1176.82.text: That is how the work’s done.

1180.10.text: So we started off using iron oxide nanoparticles

1184.21.text: and we’ve also used hyperbranched polymers.

1190.82.text:
So we found that there is an antigen that
is a marker, a biomarker,

1198.81.text:
expressed on the surface of prostate cancer
cells.

1201.60.text: It’s call prostate specific membrane antigen.

1204.73.text:
It was discovered a long time ago by one of
my colleagues,

1208.92.text: who was at Sloan Kettering Memorial then,

1211.43.text:
and now in New York and is now at Cleveland
Clinic.

1215.01.text: And it’s found on the outside of the cells.

1219.91.text:
So they made antibodies to it so that they
can actually detect it.

1225.34.text:
And in the normal epithelial of the prostate,
the normal prostate, it’s inside the cell.

1232.21.text:
And in prostate cancer it changes and goes
and sits on the outside of the cell,

1236.93.text: which means you can target it.

1240.78.text:
And it is highly expressed in prostate cancer
in lymph node metastases

1251.07.text:
And it is highly expressed in, what we call
lethal castrate-resistant prostate cancer

1258.75.text: And what is interesting about it is that,

1262.06.text:
when an antibody or something binds to the
PSMA on the surface of the cell,

1266.81.text:
it’s got a motif in the sequence of the
amino acids that make up the antigen,

1273.43.text: which carry it inside the cell.

1275.83.text:
So that means that, if we can put something
onto a molecule that’s going to bind to

1283.11.text: we can carry it inside the cell.

1284.93.text:
And our idea is to put a drug onto the PSMA
targeted nanoparticles

1291.79.text:
so that we can get a higher dose of treatment
inside the prostate cancer cells,

1298.85.text:
whilst avoiding take-up of drug in other tissues
so that you knock out the side effects

1305.79.text:
and increase the treatment where you need
the treatment.

1309.18.text:
And if you’ve got a marker such as PSMA,
and it’s found on the bone metastases

1315.13.text:
as well as on the lymph nodes as well as in
the prostate,

1318.28.text:
and you put it into the blood, it should go
and find those cancers,

1323.32.text:
and then it can knock out those cancers as
well, or image them.

1329.29.text:
So it used to be used as a test called ProstaScint for
finding prostate cancer.

1335.68.text: But, unfortunately, they used and antibody

1338.49.text:
which was not made against the part that was
outside the cells

1343.02.text: but the part that was inside the cells.

1344.88.text: So it did not work very well.

1346.49.text:
But they have now found that more molecules
that bind to PSMA

1352.22.text: can be used for PET imaging.

1355.88.text: What we did was we used iron oxide nanoparticles

1360.34.text: because when you use iron in MRI it goes darker,

1367.81.text:
so it enhances the image that you can get
with normal MRI.

1372.78.text: And so I’ve shown that here.

1376.30.text:
We made a particle like this with lots of
arms on it

1383.26.text:
and we attached an antibody against PSMA or
J591

1388.24.text:
which binds to the outside of the PSMA on
the cell.

1392.34.text: And when you inject that into a mouse,

1395.06.text:
and just actually inject it into the mouse
prostate to see what would happen,

1399.31.text:
because we were not really sure what we were
looking for,

1401.58.text:
you could see you get this terrific darkening
effect by the nanoparticles that are targeted.

1409.01.text:
Then we found that they were nontoxic to prostate
cancer cells

1413.42.text:
so we grew the cells and they didn’t die
in the presence of those.

1417.14.text:
So that’s important if you are going to
start putting them into a patient.

1423.44.text:
And we also showed that they were taken up
by the cells

1428.99.text:
so these show fluorescent binding so we put
a fluorescent marker on nanoparticles

1433.94.text:
and you can see that it’s gone into the
prostate cancer cells there at the bottom.

1441.10.text:
And here we’ve got, because the nanoparticles
are made of iron,

1446.02.text:
there is a stain that picks up iron and so
you can see here that,

1449.33.text:
in the presence of the antibody they’re
taken up much better

1453.93.text:
than when they are by themselves without the
antibody.

1457.92.text:
And you get a lot of blue staining inside
the tissue.

1466.02.text:
So then we did an experiment where we had
mice

1469.67.text: that were injected with prostate cancer cells,

1472.42.text:
and the prostate cancer was actually injected
into the prostate of the mice,

1477.27.text:
which is quite a tricky operation because
it is very small.

1481.55.text:
And then we either injected the mice that
were carrying the tumours

1487.06.text: with nanoparticles alone or targeted nanoparticles.

1490.03.text:
So the nanoparticles alone are on the left
and the targeted ones are on the right.

1495.38.text:
And we looked after two hours and after twenty-four
hours with MRI

1499.31.text:
and you can see that blackening effect that
we’re getting;

1501.74.text:
see the red arrow on the right, and similarly
at twenty four hours.

1507.85.text:
and showed that we could increase the ability
to see the tumour in this way.

1515.57.text:
And you can see as I mentioned the blue stain
before.

1519.09.text: Up at the top is the tumour grown in the mice,

1522.95.text:
and with nanoparticles alone you got a little
bit of uptake,

1526.95.text:
but when you had the nanoparticles with the
antibody you got a lot of uptake.

1531.98.text:
And it did go a little bit to the spleen and
the liver, but really not very much.

1535.72.text:
So we were not getting very much uptake in
other organs.

1538.65.text:
We were only getting it in the prostate tissue
off that cancer tissue.

1544.87.text:
So from that we decided that the nanoparticles
were safe in the normal prostate.

1551.12.text: And when we labelled them with the antibodies

1553.69.text:
we get much better uptake by cancer cells
and that enhances the MRI.

1558.13.text:
And so they have the potential to be used
as an imaging tool in patients.

1564.08.text:
Now some people have used nanoparticles before
in patients that are made of iron

1570.33.text:
and unfortunately it caused some pain and
a few toxic effects in patients.

1575.32.text:
So we did all this work, but now it hasn’t
moved into the clinic,

1580.85.text: because there could be some problems.

1583.19.text: So we are trying to develop some other methods.

1587.27.text:
So the next thing was we’ve used this hyperbranched
polymers.

1591.91.text: And they’re a type of nanoparticle.

1594.59.text:
Because they’re hyperbranched you can stick
things on the branches.

1598.92.text:
So if you think of an octopus with all these
arms everywhere,

1603.61.text: we can put a targeting agent on it.

1605.45.text: We can put an imaging agent on.

1607.39.text:
We can put a drug on that gets delivered and
so on.

1610.68.text:
So that was our idea, and that’s just to
show.

1614.05.text:
And we tried both a peptide that was made
from an antibody,

1620.59.text: which is a smaller molecule than an antibody.

1623.04.text:
We tried the antibody and we tried a very
small molecule.

1626.87.text:
Or we tried the hyperbranched polymers with
nothing attached,

1630.12.text:
and put them into mice in the same way with
tumours.

1634.81.text:
So we wanted to compare the efficacy of the
three

1642.27.text:
When you say PSMA minus, do some prostate
cancer cells not have PSMA?

1650.61.text:
In the body all prostate cancer cells have
PSMA.

1654.36.text:
In the laboratory we disable PSMA on some
prostate cancer cells. We call these PSMA

1660.96.text: Pause the video here to read more.

1666.82.text:
and we did some imaging studies after we’d
done the in vitro work

1671.88.text:
to show we chose the best one for in vivo
studies.

1677.34.text:
So we could show here by what’s called flow
cytometry

1682.05.text:
that we had cells that express PSMA and cells
that did not express PSMA,

1687.92.text: which were a control one for the other.

1690.60.text:
And you can see the red ones are the ones
that express PSMA

1693.98.text: and the black ones are the ones that don’t.

1697.06.text: And when we treated cells in tissue culture

1699.61.text:
we got much more staining of the ones that
were PSMA positive

1703.90.text: as you can see it each time and at each dose.

1712.87.text:
we were getting terrific uptake of the hyperbranched
polymer with the peptide

1717.77.text:
compared with what’s being taken up in the
cells that don’t express the PSMA ligand.

1724.66.text:
And similarly, with the antibody, so we got
that working with both.

1731.78.text: And we could show again, using confocal microscopy,

1735.65.text: that we were getting uptake of the nanoparticles,

1738.81.text:
which were labelled with the green fluorescence
marker.

1741.73.text:
You can see there the very strong green fluorescence
with those two molecules there.

1751.41.text: So then we did a mouse experiment,

1753.07.text:
and in this time we had the tumours labelled
with a red fluorescence marker

1757.87.text:
so we could see them with special imaging
equipment.

1762.82.text:
And we put the ones that had PSMA positive
on one side

1767.66.text:
and the ones with PSMA negative on the other
side.

1771.47.text:
And you can see when we injected our theranostic
hyperbranched polymer

1776.82.text: with the peptide attached that binds to PSMA,

1779.83.text:
we got really good imaging of the ones on
the right, which were PSMA positive,

1785.20.text:
and there wasn’t any imaging of the ones
on the left.

1787.80.text:
So now we’re not looking at red, we’re
looking at green fluorescence.

1790.64.text:
But you can see in the red circle there that
you are getting very good uptake,

1796.14.text: so that means that its got imaging potential.

1800.76.text:
And in addition, after we’d done the imaging,
we euthanized the mice

1806.23.text: and we took out the various organs

1808.38.text:
and looked to see how much fluorescence we
were getting in any other organs.

1812.99.text:
You can see here this is PSMA positive tumour
and the PSMA negative tumour

1821.53.text: and the liver and kidneys and spleen.

1821.69.text: So it was quite specific for prostate cancer.

1826.72.text:
And then we used a small molecule and did
the same thing.

1831.69.text:
But instead of doing fluorescence imaging
we’ve done imaging using PET.

1838.04.text:
So in this case you have to use a radio-active
isotope,

1841.14.text:
which is a attached to what’s binding to
the PSMA.

1845.84.text:
And you can see on the bottom we haven’t
got any staining of the tumour,

1851.12.text: whereas up the top we have very good staining.

1853.69.text:
Now we use copper 64, but they don’t use
that so much in the clinic, but they can,

1860.06.text:
and we just did not have the right apparatus
to make the other radio isotopes.

1867.78.text: But they are now doing it in the clinic.

1871.37.text:
So, just before I move on to that, you can
see from those data

1876.70.text:
that we were getting good binding both in
tissue culture, that’s in vitro and in vivo,

1882.82.text:
where we can image the tumours better with
these PSMA targeted molecules.

1890.54.text:
So now we’re ready, we’ve added the drug
on.

1896.48.text:
It’s taken 18 months of chemistry to be
able to add the drug on to those

1900.94.text: and we’re ready to test them.

1902.76.text: So the chemists have been working,

1904.28.text:
my colleagues have been working very hard
to get them on.

1907.84.text:
But before that, what they’ve done is, instead
of using Docetaxel,

1912.77.text:
they used just a trial drug which is bound
to the polymers with hydrazone linkage,

1923.06.text: which comes off when you change the Ph.

1928.24.text:
And when it goes inside the cell and goes
to the lysosome

1932.05.text:
the Ph drops down to five or six instead of
being at seven.

1939.94.text:
And so we can show that at Ph 5 the polymer
remains intact,

1952.39.text:
sorry at Ph 7 the polymer remains intact,
but when we drop the Ph to 5,

1960.02.text: So that would happen inside the cell.

1962.19.text: So we’ve now attached the Docetaxel

1964.49.text:
and we’re waiting to do those experiments
straight after Christmas.

1967.92.text: So we hope that it works.

1970.48.text:
Now the other thing I wanted to tell you is
that there is a model of prostate cancer.

1977.09.text:
The only animal, only mammal, which gets prostate
cancer apart from man is the dog.

1986.03.text: So mice don’t get prostate cancer.

1993.51.text:
And the prostate cancer that happens in dogs
is like the very late stage cancer.

1998.40.text: So it’s not like the early stage cancer.

2002.03.text:
So, as I mentioned, the other thing about
it within dogs

2007.55.text:
is that the cancers that form in the bone
are osteoblastic so they are making more bone,

2013.62.text: which is what happens in prostate cancer.

2015.72.text:
In breast cancer, when people get cancer that
goes in the bone, it’s holey.

2020.54.text: It’s got holes all over the place.

2023.19.text: So it’s osteoporotic instead of osteoblastic.

2025.70.text:
So prostate cancer is very different in that
it forms these very unusual bone metastases.

2031.67.text:
There is a lot of homology between dog and
human genes.

2037.93.text:
More than between mouse and human as you might
imagine from evolution.

2043.74.text:
And the PSMA is actually expressed in the
dog

2046.54.text:
and people have used small molecules to image
the dog tumours.

2055.59.text:
What we are going to do is there is a new
large core PET, where you could do dog work,

2063.20.text:
at the University of Queensland in the Centre
of Advanced Imaging.

2066.87.text: And we got a grant to buy that recently.

2069.59.text:
In talking to the vets who look after the
animal hospitals

2076.37.text:
they get about five dogs a month which get
advanced prostate cancer.

2080.83.text:
So we will try once we get it working in mice
and use the Docetaxel,

2086.11.text:
we will try it in dogs as a sort of half-way
house to trying to get into a clinical trial.

2096.30.text:
We are also doing a clinical trial of a new
PET agent,

2103.14.text: which is actually binding to prostate cancer.

2107.04.text:
This was developed in Heidelberg in Germany
and the guys at Royal Brisbane Hospital,

2115.90.text:
a guy called Paul Thomas, who does Pet imaging,
has got all the methodology

2120.56.text:
and so we’ve done a small trial where we’ve
looked at twenty men.

2125.64.text:
We’ve done MRI in the men, we’ve done
Pet imaging in the men, with this new agent,

2131.42.text:
and we’ve done a prostatectomy and then
taken the prostate’s out

2134.86.text:
and done whole mount pathology and compared
the binding

2139.25.text:
that we’ve got by the imaging by MRI with
the imaging by PET

2145.31.text: and where the prostate cancer is in the prostate.

2153.05.text:
I mentioned before that you can only detect
lymph node tumours

2157.13.text: that are perhaps greater than eight millimetres.

2160.85.text:
With this new agent you can detect tumours
that are probably 2.5 millimetres,

2168.55.text:
so you can detect smaller tumours and this
is showing enormous promise

2173.09.text:
and everyone around the world has jumped on
to this new method

2176.00.text: for doing imaging of prostate cancers.

2185.62.text: And not only that, here it is with Gallium.

2190.33.text:
If you label it with a different molecule
which is called Lutetium, 177-Lutetium,

2205.19.text:
The guy that developed the PSMA and found
the PSMA as a biomarker,

2211.64.text: Skip Heston, who is a colleague of mine,

2214.49.text:
sent me this photo that’s got some kind
of award as the best photo of the year.

2219.92.text:
And you can see on the right, on the left
hand side on the right, there’s a couple

2225.84.text:
The two black spots, we see that here in the
middle.

2233.70.text: And after treatment they’ve completely disappeared

2234.38.text: and the PSA has dropped from 38 to 4.6.

2238.49.text:
And at Peter Mac they’ve done eight patients
now who have advanced cancer,

2244.94.text:
have failed all of the other treatments that
they’ve been given,

2248.51.text:
with this new PSMA targeted PET labelled with
Lutetium and they’re responding

2256.91.text: and their tumours are going away.

2260.77.text:
It’s very early days, but there’s great
excitement that this is going to revolutionise

2267.75.text:
and perhaps provide a better treatment to
follow up on the other treatments.

2272.40.text: So PSMA Pet can detect lymph nodes

2279.12.text:
and you can actually get better results in
those patient

2283.13.text:
if you use the PET in order to find where
the lymph nodes are.

2293.06.text:
And one of our colleagues Ian Vela whose come
back from working in Sloan Kettering,

2300.73.text:
has worked out a method for actually growing
very tiny tumours in tissue culture

2308.20.text:
They call them avatards and avertoroids and
all sorts of things.

2313.70.text:
and he’s brought back some of the tumours
that he got growing in America for us to work

2320.40.text:
And he’s taken biopsies of those tiny tumours
that we were picking up with the PSMA

2327.68.text:
and put them into tissue culture to prove
that in fact they are prostate cancers

2332.27.text:
and he’s been growing some of those up for
us to do more experimental work with.

2338.15.text: So, in summary, we use the theranostics.

2342.33.text:
We call them theranostics because they can
be used for diagnosis imaging and therapy.

2349.25.text: That’s the new word that’s being used.

2353.72.text:
And they can be multiply decorated with various
agents to do PET and also treatments.

2360.18.text:
We’re targeting them and hoping that we’ll
be able to show

2365.61.text:
that the Docetaxel or Cabazitaxel works better
when it’s targeted.

2370.71.text: Both can now be done with radiotherapy.

2374.30.text:
We’ve attached a model drug to show that
its released at the Ph that happens inside

2380.85.text:
and we’ll be able to verify our findings
in dogs, we hope.

2387.09.text:
And we’re also conducting some clinical
trials.

2389.84.text: So I’d just like to thank all my collaborators.

2393.74.text:
These guys in the middle at the Centre for Advanced
Imaging

2399.49.text: and the Australian Institute of Bioengineering

2402.02.text:
are the chemists who have been doing all the
chemical work for us.

2406.57.text:
Brian and Mei have been doing all the biological
work and the animal work.

2411.97.text:
Skip Heston has given us some of the reagents
and we’ve had various funding.

2416.62.text:
So this is the group from the Australian Prostate
Cancer Research Centre.

2421.34.text:
It’s quite a big group now, so it’s firing
along.
